channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pope Francis Calls for Peace in South Sudan During Visit
item.description: Pope Francis ended his trip to Africa on Saturday by meeting with displaced people and urging his clergy not to “remain neutral before the pain caused by acts of injustice and violence.”
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Francis meeting leaders of the Roman Catholic Church on Saturday at the Cathedral of St. Therese in Juba, South Sudan’s capital.

item.title: What’s the Correct Color of Bees? In Austria, It’s a Toxic Topic.
item.description: In the Austrian state of Carinthia, where the law favors light-colored local bees, those honey producers judged “too dark” risk eradication.
item.dc:creator: Denise Hruby
item.media:credit: Ciril Jazbec for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sandro Huter checking his bees in Carinthia, Austria.

item.title: Spy Balloon Incident Highlights Fragile State of U.S.-China Relations
item.description: Recent efforts by Beijing to mend ties with Washington were showing progress, but the balloon’s appearance over the United States illustrates lingering mistrust and growing tensions.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Stefani Reynolds
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, right, in July with China’s foreign minister at the time, Wang Yi, in Bali, Indonesia.

item.title: Russia Pushes to Take Ukrainian Town Near a Vital Supply Line
item.description: Ukraine has used the strategic town of Vuhledar to launch attacks disrupting transit on a critical rail link between the war’s southern and eastern fronts.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Chris McGrath/Getty Images
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers covered their ears as an M109 self-propelled artillery unit was fired at Russian mortar positions around the strategic town of Vuhledar in December.

item.title: When It Comes to Building Its Own Defense, Europe Has Blinked
item.description: Despite expectations that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine would force Europe to bolster its military strength, it has instead reinforced dependency on U.S. leadership, intelligence and might.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with an American-made M777 howitzer last year in the Donetsk region.

item.title: U.S. Presses Turkey and U.A.E. to Weed Out Illicit Trade With Russia
item.description: American officials worry that commercial activities in Turkey and the United Arab Emirates could be fueling Russia’s war machine and have threatened to punish those involved.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Katarina Premfors for The New York Times
item.media:description: Since the war in Ukraine began last February, the United Arab Emirates has become a major destination for wealthy Russians, who have parked their yachts in its marinas and moved into its high rises.

item.title: In London’s Poor‌ ‌Areas, Budget Cuts‌ and Youth Violence Collide
item.description: Poor neighborhoods that have been hit hardest by austerity have also seen violence among young people surge or remain stubbornly high. Residents say that’s no coincidence.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Marcus Lipton Youth Club in South London in August. The center used to count on hundreds of thousands of pounds a year in government funding. Now, it gets almost none.

item.title: Missing From Czech Spa Town Popular With Russians: Russians
item.description: Since the 18th century, Russians have flocked to the healing waters of Karlovy Vary. Now, the Czech government has barred them from visiting the country, and the town must reinvent itself.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees from Ukraine singing folk songs at a rally last month in Karlovy Vary, Czech Republic.

item.title: E.U. Vows More Help for Ukraine but Tamps Down Membership Talk
item.description: European Union leaders met in Kyiv with President Volodymyr Zelensky, who said Ukraine would not give up on Bakhmut, the eastern city caught in a fierce battle with Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo released by Ukraine’s government showing President Volodymyr Zelensky, center, with the E.U. leaders Ursula von der Leyen and Charles Michel in Kyiv on Friday.

item.title: Corporate Lawyer’s Unlikely Mission: Defend and ‘Humanize’ a Hated Terrorist
item.description: Stanislas Eskenazi volunteered with Brussels’ legal aid service, typically helping petty criminals. But now he is representing Belgium’s most-wanted man.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Stephanie Lecocq
item.media:description: Stanislas Eskenazi, right, the defense lawyer of Mohamed Abrini, with other defense lawyers, at the opening of the trial of those accused of carrying out the terrorist attacks in Brussels in March of 2016.

item.title: Blinken Cancels China Trip After Spy Balloon Detected Over U.S.
item.description: The Pentagon called the object, which has flown from Montana to Kansas, an “intelligence gathering” balloon. Beijing said it was used mainly for weather research and had strayed off course.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Helene Cooper and Chris Buckley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Saul Loeb/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: What Weapons Is Ukraine Getting, and Will They Arrive in Time?
item.description: Kyiv has been promised scores of tanks and other armor, and the longest range munitions yet. But with a looming Russian offensive, a race is on to get the matériel to the battlefield.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Bulent Kilic/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has pushed for Patriot air defense systems to protect infrastructure from Russian airstrikes.

item.title: Italian Mobster, 16 Years on the Lam, Found Working at a Pizzeria
item.description: Edgardo Greco, 63, was arrested as he was about to start a night shift at a restaurant in France. Investigators identified him through online photographs.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Antonio Parrinello/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers outside the hide-out of Matteo Messina Denaro, Italy’s most wanted mafia boss, after his January arrest. Mr. Messina Denaro lived a glitzy life; the most recent fugitive arrested did not.

item.title: Man Convicted of Treason Over Threat to Kill Queen With Crossbow
item.description: The conviction, the first on such a charge in Britain in more than 40 years, came after officers stopped a man at a gate leading to the monarch’s private quarters on Christmas Day in 2021.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Carlos Jasso/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A van believed to be transporting Jaswant Singh Chail arriving at a court in London in August. Mr. Chail’s intrusion at Windsor Castle prompted the British government to review rules on the purchase of crossbows.

item.title: Chile Wildfires Leave 13 Dead
item.description: More than 150 fires burning in the country have also destroyed thousands of acres of forest, as the country faces a scorching heat wave.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Jose Carvajal/Reuters
item.media:description: Firefighters in Quilmo, near Chillán, Chile, on Thursday.

item.title: Traveling and Eating Well
item.description: When you travel, is tracking down a fantastic meal just as important as seeing the sights? I have tips to help.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson

item.title: Some Homeless Encampments Can Stay, but the Underlying Issues Remain
item.description: Three court decisions have now ruled that the shelter system does not meet the needs of homeless people.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Toronto has been aggressive when it comes to removing homeless people from encampments.

item.title: The Pentagon Saw a Warship Boondoggle. Congress Saw Jobs.
item.description: After years of crippling problems and a changing mission, the Navy pushed to retire nine of its newest ships. Then the lobbying started.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Thomas Simonetti for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of Freedom-class littoral combat ships tied up at port in Jacksonville, Fla. Eight of the 10 based there were slated for retirement, but the Navy reversed itself on four of them.

item.title: Ties to Kabul Bombing Put ISIS Leader in Somalia in U.S. Cross Hairs
item.description: Bilal al-Sudani’s financing of the ISIS branch in Afghanistan that killed 13 U.S. troops in 2021 elevated him on U.S. kill-or-capture lists.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victims of a suicide attack at the Kabul airport on Aug. 26, 2021. The double bombing killed nearly 200 people, including 13 U.S. service members.

item.title: Before Chinese Spy Balloon Sighting, Classified Report Highlighted Foreign Aerial Spying
item.description: Before a Chinese spy balloon was discovered in the United States, American officials said a rival power may have used advanced technology to surveil U.S. military sites.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Uli Seit for The New York Times
item.media:description: A black drone flying over trees and grass in Bayside, Queens.

item.title: Brazil Says It’s Started Sinking an Old Warship, Hazardous Material and All
item.description: The navy said it had begun an operation to send the aircraft carrier São Paulo to the bottom.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Brazilian Navy, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: São Paulo in the Atlantic off Rio de Janeiro in 2011. Once the flagship of the Brazilian Navy, it had not seen active service in roughly a decade.

item.title: A Giant Balloon Was Spotted in Montana. It’s All Anyone Can Talk About.
item.description: A Chinese balloon has been raising a lot of questions for people who live under its path. “I did see it, and it should have been shot,” said a barbecue chef in Billings, Mont.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins
item.media:credit: Larry Mayer/The Billings Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A high-altitude balloon floating over Billings, Mont., on Wednesday.

item.title: Chinese Spy Balloon or ‘Civilian Device’? Here’s What We Know So Far
item.description: Here is what we know about the balloon.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Larry Mayer/The Billings Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A high-altitude balloon floating over Billings, Mont., on Wednesday. The Pentagon has not confirmed whether the photo shows the Chinese “intelligence-gathering balloon” it described.

item.title: Metal Detector Hobbyist Finds a 500-Year-Old Pendant Linked to Henry VIII
item.description: Researchers say the jewelry, found in a field outside Birmingham, England, is an extraordinary piece of treasure.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images
item.media:description: The gold, heart-shaped pendant has symbols connected to Henry VIII and his first wife, Katherine of Aragon.

item.title: Fears of Russian Nuclear Weapons Use Have Diminished for Now
item.description: Nearly a year into the war in Ukraine, U.S. policymakers and intelligence analysts have more confidence that they understand at least some of President Vladimir V. Putin’s red lines.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Valery Sharifulin
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, a senior U.S. official said recently, may well have come to the conclusion that his nuclear threats were backfiring.

item.title: Gary Glitter Is Released From Prison After Serving Half of His Sentence
item.description: The disgraced former glam rock singer was found guilty in 2015 of sexually abusing three young girls in the 1970s. He had been given a 16-year sentence.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Justin Tallis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Paul Gadd, better known by his stage name, Gary Glitter, arrived at court in London in 2015. He has been released after spending eight years in prison.

item.title: Germany to Allow Export of Older Leopard 1 Tanks to Ukraine
item.description: An older model than the already approved Leopard 2, the tanks will need refurbishment and could face ammunition shortages.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Yves Herman/Reuters
item.media:description: German-made Leopard 1 tanks in a hangar in Tournais, Belgium, on Tuesday.

item.title: Why Eggs Cost So Much
item.description: Inflation, avian flu and war have made a food staple much more expensive.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Wu
item.media:credit: Neeta Satam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cackle Hatchery in Lebanon, Mo.

item.title: Hong Kong To Give Away 500,000 Plane Tickets to Lure Tourists
item.description: The city’s reputation has been hammered by protests, a harsh security law and strict Covid measures. It hopes a giveaway of 500,000 plane tickets woos back tourists.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Tyrone Siu/Reuters
item.media:description: John Lee, the chief executive of Hong Kong, discussing a campaign to promote tourism in the city.

item.title: A New Approach to Funding for the Arts
item.description: A new government policy, called Revive, will prioritize Indigenous arts and culture, and also provide funding for commercial arts forms, like popular music.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Bianca De Marchi/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: An art installation during the Vivid Festival in Sydney last year.

item.title: Pope Francis Visits South Sudan to Highlight Young Nation’s Troubles
item.description: The soaring hopes at South Sudan’s creation in 2011 have been cruelly dashed. Pope Francis arrived in the country on Friday and immediately offered blunt criticism of its leaders.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Jason Horowitz and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A street scene in Juba, South Sudan.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russian losses in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Near Kyiv, mourning a soldier killed in the fighting in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Court Dismisses Guilty Plea by Australian Tennis Star Nick Kyrgios in Assault Case
item.description: The guilty plea and dismissal stemmed from a confrontation Mr. Kyrgios had with his partner in 2021 when she tried to prevent him from leaving in a ride-hailing car.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mick Tsikas/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Nick Kyrgios arriving at court in Canberra, Australia, on Friday.

item.title: Pentagon Says It Detected a Chinese Spy Balloon Hovering Over Montana
item.description: The revelation comes days before Secretary of State Antony Blinken’s visit to Beijing, where he is expected to meet with President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Senior Airman Tristan Day/U.S. Air Force, via Associated Press
item.media:description: In an image provided by the U.S. Air Force, an airman working on an intercontinental ballistic missile at Malmstrom Air Force Base in Montana. The Pentagon said a surveillance balloon was hovering over the state on Wednesday.

item.title: As Russia Strikes Ukrainian Civilians, Putin Tells His People the War Is Just
item.description: Invoking World War II on the 80th anniversary of victory at Stalingrad, Mr. Putin repeated his false justifications for an invasion that has taken a staggering toll.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Anton Troianovski
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the rubble of an apartment building destroyed by a Russian attack, emergency workers in Kramatorsk searched for survivors on Thursday.

item.title: Biden Aims to Deter China With Greater U.S. Military Presence in Philippines
item.description: U.S. officials say they are preparing to surge forces in the event of conflict with China, including over Taiwan, but do not intend to build up permanent bases.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Bullit Marquez/Associated Press
item.media:description: The new agreement allows the United States to put military equipment and build facilities in nine locations across the Philippines.

item.title: Soaring Russian Death Toll in Ukraine Gives Grim Insight Into the War
item.description: Moscow is sending poorly trained recruits, including convicts, to the front lines in eastern Ukraine to pave the way for more seasoned fighters, U.S. and allied officials say.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian medical evacuation team members await calls for wounded soldiers in the Donbas region in eastern Ukraine, which has been the scene of heavy fighting.

item.title: U.S. Says Russian Olympians Should Only Compete as Neutral Participants
item.description: The stance differs from the full ban demanded by Ukraine and supported by some of its allies.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russia’s Olympic athletes, including the figure skater Anna Shcherbakova, participated in the last Winter Olympics under the name and flag of the Russian Olympic Committee.

item.title: Peru Official Concedes There’s No Evidence Criminals Are Behind Protests
item.description: In an interview, Foreign Minister Ana Cecilia Gervasi acknowledged “we don’t have any evidence” that weeks of protests were being driven by criminal groups, as the country’s president has claimed.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Marco Garro for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against the government of President Dina Boluarte last month in Lima, Peru.

item.title: High-Profile Raids Showcase Zelensky’s Corruption Crackdown in Ukraine
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky is eager to highlight his crackdown on corruption, ahead of E.U. accession talks and possible Western investigations of war aid.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Office
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has pivoted to a policy of high-profile anti-corruption enforcement this year.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: The U.S. Military Expands in the Philippines
item.description: Also, Vladimir Putin evokes Stalingrad and a contested film is a box-office hit in India.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Rolex Dela Pena
item.media:description: US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin reviewing honor guards upon arrival at the Department of National Defense at Camp Aguinaldo military camp in Quezon City, Metro Manila on Thursday.

item.title: Britain to Investigate if Deadliest Attack of Northern Ireland’s ‘Troubles’ Was Preventable
item.description: The decision is a big victory for the families of the 29 people who died in the attack in August 1998, four months after the signing of the Good Friday Agreement.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Paul Mcerlane/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The scene of a bomb explosion on Market Street in Omagh, Northern Ireland, on Aug. 15, 1998.

item.title: In Congo, a Pope and a Nation Revitalize Each Other
item.description: Francis has been slowed by age. But his enthusiastic welcome in Africa has proved a shot in the arm and provided a reminder of the papacy’s global reach.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Arsene Mpiana/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pope Francis on Thursday at Martyrs’ Stadium in Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo. He addressed some 65,000 young people.

item.title: Israel’s Government Pushes Home Demolitions as Violence Surges
item.description: Israel defends its policy of leveling the family homes of Palestinians accused of attacks on its citizens as a deterrent. Critics say it is illegal and ineffective.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Afif H. Amireh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers outside the home of the al-Qam family on Sunday. Khairy al-Qam, 21, was recently accused of killing seven people outside a synagogue.

item.title: Tortured Guantánamo Detainee Is Freed in Belize
item.description: Majid Khan, a Pakistani citizen who attended high school in Maryland, finished his sentence last year.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A Proud Ship Turned Into a Giant Recycling Problem. So Brazil Plans to Sink It.
item.description: The old aircraft carrier, once the navy’s flagship, is packed with asbestos. No country, including Brazil, will let it dock to be dismantled.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Instituto São Paulo | Foch
item.media:description: The São Paulo, a Clemenceau-class carrier laid down in 1957, has not seen active service in roughly a decade.

item.title: European Parliament Strips 2 Lawmakers of Immunity in Graft Inquiry
item.description: The European Parliament’s move is likely to prompt the arrest of Marc Tarabella of Belgium and Andrea Cozzolino of Italy in connection with claims of influence-peddling involving Qatar and Morocco.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Yves Herman/Reuters; John Thys, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Marc Tarabella of Belgium, left, and Andrea Cozzolino of Italy, right, are members of the center-left Socialists and Democrats group, which is at the heart of the scandal ripping through the European Parliament.

item.title: Window Stickers to Prevent Bird Strikes Only Work One Way
item.description: Every year, hundreds of millions of birds die in the United States from flying into glass. New research shows how to prevent some of those deaths.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: William Mullins/Alamy
item.media:description: Other big threats to birds: Habitat lost to development, climate change and hunting by cats.

item.title: Encouraging Economic Signs
item.description: New data suggests a promising possibility for the economy — that the U.S. avoids big job losses.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell.

item.title: Top E.U. Officials Arrive in Kyiv for a Summit With Zelensky
item.dc:creator: Erin Mendell
item.media:credit: Efrem Lukatsky/Associated Press
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky and Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, greeting each other during the E.U.-Ukraine summit in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. and Philippines Have a Complex Military Alliance: What to Know
item.description: The United States and the Philippines have announced a plan to broaden American military access. The alliance is complicated by colonial history and rising tensions over Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Rolex Dela Pena
item.media:description: Lloyd J. Austin III, the U.S. defense secretary, center, arriving at Camp Aguinaldo, a military base in Quezon City, the Philippines, on Thursday.

item.title: After Jacinda Ardern, Politics Will Never Look the Same
item.description: For once, a politician who wasn’t afraid of fashion.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Hannah Peters/Getty Images
item.media:description: Jacinda Ardern, the former prime minister of New Zealand, wore a burgundy jacket and matching shirt by the New Zealand label Maaike at her election night party in 2017, setting the tone for how fashion would figure into her leadership.

item.title: A U.S. Ambassador Finds Himself on Hostile Ground in Hungary
item.description: David Pressman, a gay human rights lawyer, has been accused by pro-government media in Hungary of undermining traditional values, violating diplomatic conventions and meddling in the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Pressman posing for a portrait in front of the former National TV headquarters last month in Budapest.

item.title: Australia Won’t Put King Charles on Its 5-Dollar Bill
item.description: The bill had long featured Queen Elizabeth II, but officials said the bank note would be redesigned to focus on Indigenous history. That has rekindled the debate about republicanism in Australia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mick Tsikas/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Australia’s prime minister, Anthony Albanese, stands next to a portrait of King Charles III in Canberra, Australia, last month. The longstanding images of the British sovereign will be replaced by an Indigenous element on the 5-dollar note.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The start of a new Russian offensive.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces training in the Zaporizhzhia region on Monday.

item.title: China and the U.S. Are Wooing Indonesia, and Beijing Has the Edge
item.description: The resource-laden nation of nearly 300 million is a big prize in the strategic battle between the United States and China for influence in Asia.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez, Eric Schmitt and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portrait of China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and Indonesia’s leader, Joko Widodo, at a construction site in Bandung, Indonesia, where a high-speed train station is being built.

item.title: U.S. to Boost Military Role in the Philippines in Push to Counter China
item.description: Washington and Manila announced a plan to give the American military access to four new locations in the Southeast Asian country, a growing strategic partner in the region.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jam Sta Rosa
item.media:description: President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. of The Philippines and United States Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin at the presidential palace in Manila, on Thursday.

item.title: What ‘No’ on F-16 Fighter Jets Might Mean for Ukraine
item.description: If the usual script plays out, the Biden administration’s reluctance to provide the planes could be temporary, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Thaier Al-Sudani/Reuters
item.media:description: Ukraine has asked for dozens of F-16s, which were developed in the 1970s by General Dynamics and the U.S. Air Force.

item.title: How an American Veterans Group Imploded in Ukraine
item.description: The Mozart Group was training Ukrainian soldiers and evacuating frontline residents until the money ran out. Its collapse sheds light on the stresses faced by such groups.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rob, left, a member of the Mozart Group, training Ukrainian soldiers last year.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Rising Militancy in Pakistan
item.description: Also, Adani Enterprises pulls its offering and soldiers die on both sides in Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Arshad Arbab/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The bombing of a mosque in Peshawar, Pakistan, knocked the city back in time, to an era where terrorist attacks were more prevalent.

item.title: A Couple Danced in Tehran’s Streets. Now They Are in Prison.
item.description: Iranian authorities sentenced a young couple to five years in prison after they posted a video of themselves dancing in the streets at the height of the country’s protests.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Images from a video posted on social media showing Astiyazh Haghighi and Amir Mohammad Ahmadi dancing in front of Tehran’s Azadi Tower.
